bestBHT.bht: The use of uncommon phrases like them that had been with him and disciples is noteworthy, as well as the unique absolute use of the pronoun and the verb went. The disciples are described as mourning and weeping, deeply saddened by the loss of their Lord and their own actions towards him. The women play a significant role in conveying the news of Jesus' resurrection to the disciples, who likely did not anticipate such a remarkable event.

Henry Alford: This idiom, never used by St. Mark, is three times contained in this passage (vv. 12, 15).
Them that had been with him, though found in the Acts (xx. 18), never occurs in the Gospels.
Nor does the word 'disciples' in this passage.
Marvin Vincent: An absolute use of the pronoun unexampled in Mark." (Commentary)
Went, go. This verb for to go occurs nowhere else in this Gospel except in compounds." (Commentary)
A circumlocution foreign to the Gospels." (Commentary)
Philip Schaff: Emphasis seems to rest on the word 'she;' she was the first to tell them, the others probably returning later, after they had seen the Lord on the way.
An unusual expression for 'disciples,' probably including the whole company of His followers.
A natural touch, showing how little they anticipated His resurrection.
Archibald T. Robertson: Went (πορευθεισα). First aorist passive participle. Common word for going, but in Mark so far only in Mark 9:30 in the uncompounded form."
Them that had been with him (τοις μετ' αυτου γενομενοις). This phrase for the disciples occurs here alone in Mark and the other Gospels if the disciples (μαθητα) are meant."

As they mourned and wept (πενθουσιν κα κλαιουσιν). Present active participles in dative plural agreeing with τοις ... γενομενοις and describing the pathos of the disciples in their utter bereavement and woe.
John Gill: she went, as she was bid by Christ, and told his disciples, what she had heard and seen

even those who had been with him from the beginning, and had heard his doctrines, and seen his miracles, and had had communion with him, and truly believed in him, and were his constant followers, and real disciples

As they mourned and wept, being inconsolable for the death of their Lord, and the loss of his presence; and also for their carriage towards him, that one among them should betray him, another deny him, and all forsake him

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 16:10, there are several unique elements that stand out within this passage. The use of the phrase them that had been with him and disciples is uncommon in the Gospels, as well as the absolute use of the pronoun and the verb went. The author employs a circumlocution that is foreign to the style of the Gospels. The disciples are described as mourning and weeping, illustrating their profound sadness and grief. This passage emphasizes the role of the women, particularly the first to encounter the resurrected Jesus, who then went on to inform the other disciples. The disciples, encompassing the entire company of followers, likely did not anticipate his resurrection and were devastated by their loss.

The use of unusual phrases like them that had been with him and disciples in this verse is not typical in the Gospels, as is the absolute use of the pronoun and the verb went. With a sorrowful tone, the disciples mourned and wept, overwhelmed by the loss of their Lord and their own actions towards him. The women played a vital role in conveying the news of Jesus' resurrection to the disciples, who perhaps did not anticipate such a miraculous event.

In this passage, there are several distinct elements that set it apart. The phrases them that had been with him and disciples are used uniquely and not commonly found in the Gospels. Additionally, the absolute use of the pronoun and the verb went are specific to this verse. The disciples are depicted mourning and weeping, overwhelmed by grief and their own actions toward Jesus. Notably, the women take on the crucial role of being the first to report the resurrection to the disciples, who likely did not anticipate such a miraculous event.

The use of uncommon phrases like them that had been with him and disciples is noteworthy, as well as the unique absolute use of the pronoun and the verb went. The disciples are described as mourning and weeping, deeply saddened by the loss of their Lord and their own actions towards him. The women play a significant role in conveying the news of Jesus' resurrection to the disciples, who likely did not anticipate such a remarkable event.

In this passage, the use of phrases like them that had been with him and disciples is uncommon in the Gospels. Furthermore, the absolute use of the pronoun and the verb went is unique within this context. The disciples are portrayed as mourning and weeping, overwhelmed by their grief and remorse for their actions towards Jesus. Significantly, the women take on a crucial role in being the first to inform the disciples about Jesus' resurrection, indicating that the disciples perhaps did not anticipate such a miraculous event.
